Stem on this larger one is peeling off.

results.notes:
Location: Rock Creek Park, Washington, DC
Habitat: mixed oak, beech, mountain laurel, and other hardwoods
Size: pretty large, solid, chunky, cap about 6 inches in diameter, stipe around 4 inches tall
Cap: mixed brick red/orange, bald, bruising dark blue
Pores: very small, circular, ochre, thin tube layer, bruising dark blue, fading to brown
Flesh: pale yellow, staining blue with 30 seconds
Stem: yellow, a bit of orange at the base. Some texture, but subtle and not sure how I would describe (striation v stretched out reticulation), bruising blue
Basal mycelium: white
Odor: sweet/fenugreek
Flavor: mild, pleasant
results.location_name: Rock Creek Park, Washington DC, USA

results.notes:
I’ve not previously found A. rooseveltensis on this part of my property (very common in three other locations. Two observations featuring the three fruit bodies observed. This one was more-or-less solitary, about 1 meter from the pair seen in the other observation. All three were rather dark-capped for rooseveltensis.
Spores subglobose, broadly ellipsoid, ellipsoid. But I think at least some of those appearing broadly ellipsoid are positioned to give this impression. When the spores tumble around in the mounting solution (Congo red) I can occasionally see the shapes change as per profile.
Near an apple tree with one 15 foot tall shagbark hickory close by.

results.notes:
Same location as a several other observations of this slender rubescent amanita; shady area with hickory, white ash (a few small ones have survived the ash-borer), and walnut.
Cap margin streaked with a few very short striations.
Plates of white material deposited along the small basal bulb is unusual for the amerirubescens types. Presumably uv material, but given that no pv is seen, I wonder if this cold be an annulus that slid down the stipe. I don’t think so; pv for the amerirubescens types is thin and tends to collapse onto the upper stipe.

results.notes: Morphology: conical to campanulately broadly-umbonate (rarely plane-upturned) cap whitish-beige, tip brownish often with satin-brown marginal ring; gills whitish gray-brown to deep brown, sub-distant to closely-spaced, adnexed; robust white stem somewhat hollow with fibrous-striations stains grayish-brown. Spore print: dark benzo brown. Spores: ellipsoid-ovoid, infrequently amygdaliform, citriniform or oblong [N=20] measure (12.7)13.2 – 15.8(16.3) √ó (6.9)7.4 – 8.6(9.3) ¬µm; Q = (1.5)1.6 – 2(2.3); Me = 14.2 √ó 7.9 ¬µm; Qe = 1.8. Measurements: [n = 7] cap 18.0-38.1 (avg. 27.4) mm across by 1.1-16.9 (avg. 11.3) high, stem 2.8-6.1 (avg. 3.9) thick (widest near cap, nearly equal or tapering towards base) by 41.6-71.0 (avg. 55.7) tall. Growth pattern: scattered or gregarious. Habitat: mowed grass next to an astroturf field.

results.notes:
I keep good notes and return often to a very wide range of off the beaten track trails.
At the time of taking THIS photo (I have 3 similiar shots showing all parts), I thought it was a tawny, but I am making a study of amanitas in 2023 – going back over several years of photos.
I can return to the exact place.
I frequently return to places of interest – around the original siting date – the following year.
I have been returning to an area of numerous sarcoscypha for years – wondering if climate changes will affect their emergence. I photograph the soil temps on a thermometer inserted next to the fruitings – to give a record of the data.

results.notes:
Growing on hardwood twigs among leaf litter under a canopy of Rhododendron catawbiense and Vaccinium corymbosum, with scattered Picea rubens. Caps dry; up to 5.5 mm wide and 2.6 mm tall. Gills adnate; with 1 to 2 tiers of lamellulae; some gills slightly yellow-marginate toward the stem. Stems dry; lacking a basal disc; up to 11.9 mm tall and 0/8 mm wide. Odor and taste not distinctive. Not noticeably bioluminescent. Not noticeably fluorescent under UV light. Lamellar trama dextrinoid. Clamps present in the lamellar trama. Pleurocystidia scattered and similar to cheilocystidia. Cheilocystidia forming a sterile band; hyaline; with coralloid apices. Basidia 4-sterigmate. Spores weakly amyloid, hyaline, smooth, and thin-walled. Spore measurements: (6) 6.9 – 9.4 (9.9) √ó (3) 4 – 5.8 (6) ¬µm; Q = (1.3) 1.5 – 2 (2.2); N = 30; Me = 8.2 √ó 5 ¬µm; Qe = 1.7

—

Mirrored on iNaturalist as observation 173807987 on July 19, 2023.

results.notes: Morphology: convex golden-beige cap with very thin brown marginal ring; light brown gills rather adnate-subdecurrent; whitish stem rapidly stains deep mahogany nearing black. Spore print: cream-brown to dark purplish-brown (depending upon lighting and angle of reflection). Measurements: [n=1] cap 6.56 mm across by 2.85 high, stem 1.48 thick (tapering dramatically towards base mid-way) by 19.15 tall. Growth pattern: solitary. Habitat: mowed grass at edge of woodland, growing from soil in a manner similar to that of nearby Panaeolus foenisecii and Candolleomyces candolleana.

results.notes:
Spores are 7-9.5 × 5-6 (a few with lengths approaching 10 microns). According to Mycoquebec, these are significantly larger dimensions than expected for Cotylidia diaphana. The spore photo for Tremellodendron pallidum on Mycoquebec is a very good match for these.
Clustered on the ground in mixed woods.
The names Tremellodendron pallidum, T. schweinitzii, and Sebacina schweinitzii all appear to refer to the same species. Index Fungorum says the current name is Sebacina schweinitzii.

results.notes:
This fruit body is well past prime. Given favorable conditions, these type mushrooms don’t last very long after they pop. Given that I have been finding the morphologically similar species A. rooseveltensis on new areas of my 4 acre property and that some of the latter have shown a rather dark disc, one may wonder how I distinguish between the two (provisional) species.
A. rooseveltensis: a significant percentage of spores are broadly ellipsoid, some ellipsoid.
A. cyclops: spore globose, some subglobose.
These spore differences consistently correlate with DNA data for the two taxa.

A. cyclops is restricted to the northwest corner of my property, where two 20-something year old oaks grow near a mowed path.
